questiontext.text: Briefly explain why you don't always need the same set of libraries at run-time that you need at compile-time, and why this impacts the build management process.
Explain the difference between refactoring as "just-in-time" design versus "speculative design"

Suppose you are working in a team of 4, and you ask for your code to be reviewed by your team members. Given what you have read about code reviews, do you think it is better to conduct 3 one-on-one reviews or one review with all team members present? Explain your answer.

generalfeedback.text: The correct answer is that generally it is better to review as a group. The "sum is greater than its parts" logic applies, in that 1) you save team time (which is money), and 2) you tend to find more defects and educate each other more in a group. However, there could be reasons the team reviews backfire. Maybe your team doesn't communicate well or has aggrandizing personalities. Maybe it is too hard to schedule the whole team. So individual circumstances may mean "it depends".

The amount of work remaining in a Sprint
The requirements for the product

questiontext.text: Match the terms with the definition best-suited to that term

subquestion.text: converting code from high-level abstract language to machine-level language
combining machine-level code into one large object level executable or library
combining object level code modules at run-time (during program execution)
Compiling, assembling and packaging source artifacts into deployable resources
Moving a set of deployable resources (a build) to a target environment.
An incremental modification to already deployed software typically to correct a priority defect.
The ability to deploy new software "in place"; that is, without restarting the system/application.
Modifying existing software post-release without fundamentally changing the intent, or business purpose, of the software
Deploying software in multiple steps, with each step addressing a quality requirement on the way to a production environment.
A combination of software artifacts used to build a target release
software ready to be used by a target set of customers
a deployed environment ready for use by your customers

questiontext.text: Match the terms with the best available description.

subquestion.text: Modifying or enhancing an existing product or process.
Process by which an object or structure is created.
Someone who pays for the product.
Someone who has an interest in the product.

questiontext.text: Match the phrase with the best description.

subquestion.text: Needs of potential customers are investigated
Evaluate the quality of a design
Use brainstorming, market research, or other creative activities to produce a conceptual design.
Understand idea characteristics and their advantages and disadvantages.
Evaluate and select potential designs based on Criteria and Constraints.
Develop the design in enough detail to allow working on a prototype.
Implement to characterize various aspects of design.
See whether the design meets all constraints and performs acceptably relative to criteria.
If testing and evaluation reveal a design weakness, then this may need to be done.
Produce or construct the design.
The activities and results of the design process are documented and communicated to relevant stakeholders.

Less formal than an inspection, this approach omits or combines some roles and activities.
The author leads the discussion among a group of colleagues and does not have to report data to management.

model the interaction between a system and its environment
model the organization of the system

subquestion.text: Parameter defects, such as using the wrong number or type of parameters in the call, is the most common form of this error.
The caller does not understand the specification of the interface, such as its return type, parameter semantics, or behavior.
Different processes operating at different speeds, and the interface between them does not mediate access properly.

questiontext.text: In a spiral design process, after completing the {1:SHORTANSWER:=refine the design} phase, you may have to go back to the {2:SHORTANSWER:=select a design} phase if the original design will not work.

generalfeedback.text: Use all lowercase on your short answers! p. 93

questiontext.text: A coherent user interface must integrate {1:MULTICHOICE:Mouse#~Keyboard#~=user interaction~%50%information presentation} and {2:MULTICHOICE:Mouse#~Keyboard#~%50%user interaction~=information presentation}

Interaction design is an {1:MULTICHOICE:incremental~waterfall~interactive~=iterative} process where {2:MULTICHOICE:managers~customers~=users} interact with {3:MULTICHOICE:managers~=designers~programmers} and {4:MULTICHOICE:programmers~graphic designers~=interface prototypes} to decide on the features, organization, and look and feel of the user interface.

{1:SHORTANSWER:%100%precision} is the ability of a static analyzer to exclude false positives. {2:SHORTANSWER:%100%recall} is the percentage of flaws the static analyzer found versus all flaws that are present in the code.
Behavioral models capture what happens when a system responds to a {1:SA:=stimulus}
{1:SA:=partition~50%} and {2:SA:=guideline~50%}-based testing are recommended strategies for choosing effective unit test cases.
{1:SA:=white~50%} box testing requires one to review the structure of the code, {2:SA:=black~50%} box testing only requires one to run the code with different equivalence partitions.
During the Daily Scrum the following questions are asked of each team member:

answer.text: What he or she has accomplished since the last meeting
What he or she is going to do before the next meeting

Are you a chicken or a pig?

intractable because there are too many paths to check

it will plot memory management statistics for you

questiontext.text: How is FindBugs like a static analysis tool?

answer.text: it parses and analyzes code, not an executing system
it has a code syntax highlighter
it checks for problems in comments and curly braces

questiontext.text: Features of XP testing include
Sommerville recommends automating unit tests as much as possible, an idea shared by the greater software development community. Which of the following are reasons for automating unit tests?

answer.text: tests can be run faster, often in seconds
tests results are easily aggregated and reported in a GUI
test automation frameworks provide support for rapidly implementing unit tests
as a developer, you can offload unit testing to a testing staff person

questiontext.text: Guidelines for revealing defects with equivalence partitions include

answer.text: use sequences with only one value
use sequences of varying sizes in different tests
test the 1st, last, and middle elements of a sequence
test with linearly ordered sequences, e.g. 1, 2, 3...

During development, testing may be carried out at these levels of granularity:
________ and __________-based testing are recommended strategies for choosing effective unit test cases. (choose 2 answers from below)
Benefits to test-driven development (TDD) are that it

answer.text: reduces the costs of regression tests
helps the developer understand the problem better

questiontext.text: The process by which we check that delivered software meets customer expectations is called
Team members are also known as ____. Chickens cannot tell ______ how to do their work. _____ are committed to project success.(Note the blanks all refer to the same word).
An iteration in Scrum is called a ______________
Postponing change propagation can lead to "stunningly complex" what?
In Design By Contract, the contract is a s_____
Source Lines Of Code (SLOC) and Function Points (FP) are similar in that both are measures of _____ (one word)
You should always build the ________ thing that can possibly work.
_____ strikes and you refactor
The "simulation of a real execution" of a program is called
Chickens are not allowed to talk in Daily Scrums.
In Scrum, saying that an increment of functionality is Done at the end of a Sprint means that it has been designed, coded, fully tested and packaged for use for the Product Owner.

Component interfaces come in two types: required and provides. Provided interfaces are the ones provided by an outside service to be used by this component. Required interfaces are the ones specified by the component and must be implemented by its subclasses.
Branching too often means you have too many concurrent lines of development in which to manage changes. It is more work.
Defensive Programming has renewed popularity due to the increase in interest in writing more secure software
The intent of defensive programming is to ensure the resulting software continues to function (correctly) in spite of being used in unanticipated ways.
In principle, one should couple (tie together) the desired interaction with an underlying entity so manipulation through the user interface goes smoothly.
Due to the difficulty in communication the essence of tasks to designers and end users, a notation like UML sequence diagrams should be used.

When prototyping, you should adopt a 2-stage process where early in the process you develop paper prototypes to walk through in end users, and then refine the design with increasingly sophisticated automated prototypes that users can use for testing.
When you refactor, you may end up changing a program's observable behavior
When you refactor, you may end up changing a program's nonfunctional characteristics.
In a code review, the author of the code is reviewed as well as the source code.
Static analysis can prove a body of source code is free of flaws (errors).
In class I describe one of the motivations for using static analysis to be a cost savings when compared to traditional code reviews. The paper describes the same motivation.
Structural models may be static, showing the state of the system when it is executing.
A system context model is a structural model showing how the system interacts with its environment as it is used.
There is not a simple one-to-one relationship between objects and interfaces.
A good information design guideline is to keep the code for information and information presentation tightly mingled so its works efficiently.
Graphics make your display more interesting, and therefore is better for your User Interface
If data is numeric, changes often, or if relationships are more important that precision, then you should display information graphically.
You should consider the user's background and experience when designing error messages.
Sequence diagrams defined by the UML need to express implementation level details even at the early stages of the design process
One difference between Component and System testing is that System testing is a collaborative process that may involve more people and roles than just the original developer.
Test-driven development(TDD) means the testers, as caretakers of the requirements, indicate what code should be written first.
